prompt:
---
name: A demo
inputs:
    joke: "how do you make a tissue dance? You put a little boogie in it."
---
system:
You are an assistant and you need to categorize a joke as funny or not.

user:
{{joke}}
inputSpec:
The input to the chatbot is a joke.  
The joke must be in text format.  
The length of the joke is not restricted.  
The joke can include any type of content, whether it's a pun, anecdote, or any form of humor.
rules: The output must clearly state whether a given joke is categorized as "funny" or "not funny".
The output must consist of only one of two categories: "funny" or "not funny".
The output must not include any additional comments, explanations, or justifications for the categorization.
The output must not contain any elements of the joke itself or any references to the content of the joke.
The output must be formatted as a single, standalone word that is either "funny" or "not funny".
inverseRules: A given joke must be left uncategorized as "funny" or "not funny".
The output must consist of multiple categories beyond just "funny" or "not funny".
The output must include additional comments, explanations, or justifications for the categorization.
The output must contain elements of the joke itself or references to the content of the joke.
The output must be formatted as a full sentence, not just the single words "funny" or "not funny".

tests.rule: The output must clearly state whether a given joke is categorized as "funny" or "not funny".
tests.testinput: What do you call fake spaghetti? An impasta!
tests.reasoning: The test checks that the software correctly categorizes a typical pun as 'funny'. It follows input specification by being a joke in text format.

tests.rule: The output must clearly state whether a given joke is categorized as "funny" or "not funny".
tests.testinput: Why was the math book sad? Because it had too many problems.
tests.reasoning: This test verifies if the software can categorize a classic math joke as 'funny', meeting the input specifications.

tests.rule: The output must clearly state whether a given joke is categorized as "funny" or "not funny".
tests.testinput: I have a fear of speed bumps, but I am slowly getting over it.
tests.reasoning: The input is a text-based joke with a pun, testing whether the software categorizes it correctly as 'funny'.

tests.reasoning: The test ensures the output exclusively uses predefined categories, checking compliance with input specifications.

tests.rule: The output must consist of only one of two categories: "funny" or "not funny".

tests.reasoning: This test case tests the software's ability to adhere to using only the two specified categories: 'funny' and 'not funny'.

tests.rule: The output must consist of only one of two categories: "funny" or "not funny".
tests.testinput: Did you hear about the Italian chef who died? He pasta way.
tests.reasoning: The test ensures the software outputs only 'funny' or 'not funny', in line with the input and functional specs.

tests.rule: The output must not include any additional comments, explanations, or justifications for the categorization.
tests.testinput: I threw a boomerang a few years ago. I know live in constant fear.
tests.reasoning: This test checks that output does not include extra commentary, meeting input specification by being a text joke.

tests.rule: The output must not include any additional comments, explanations, or justifications for the categorization.
tests.testinput: Why don’t skeletons fight each other? They don’t have the guts.
tests.reasoning: The test ensures the output lacks additional explanations, adhering to the succinct output format.

tests.rule: The output must not include any additional comments, explanations, or justifications for the categorization.
tests.testinput: Parallel lines have so much in common. It’s a shame they’ll never meet.
tests.reasoning: Ensures output is concise without explanations, just adhering to the defined format of categorization.

tests.rule: The output must not contain any elements of the joke itself or any references to the content of the joke.
tests.testinput: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field.
tests.reasoning: The test validates that no joke content is included in the output, only a category tag is given.

tests.rule: The output must not contain any elements of the joke itself or any references to the content of the joke.
tests.testinput: I used to play piano by ear, but now I use my hands.
tests.reasoning: Checks that the output avoids references to the joke's content, maintaining adherence to functional expectations.

tests.testinput:
category: humor
joke: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field!

category: sarcasm
joke: "I am on a seafood diet. I see food and I eat it."

category: dad joke
joke: Why can't you give Elsa a balloon? Because she will let it go.

category: pun
joke: Did you hear about that new broom? It's sweeping the nation.

category: dark humor
joke: I have a few jokes about unemployed people, but none of them work.

category: one-liner
joke: I told my wife she was drawing her eyebrows too high. She looked surprised.

category: knock-knock
joke: Knock knock. Who’s there? Lettuce. Lettuce who? Lettuce in, it’s cold out here!

category: anti-joke
joke: Why did the chicken cross the road? To get to the other side.

category: riddle
joke: What has keys but can't open locks? A piano.

category: observational humor
joke: Have you ever noticed that anyone driving slower than you is an idiot, and anyone driving faster is a maniac?

category: wordplay
joke: I’m reading a book on anti-gravity. It’s impossible to put down.

This play on words is typical of humor, as "problems" can refer to both mathematical exercises and emotional issues. 

There are no predefined restrictions on the joke's content, and it is coherent enough to be categorized as a joke. The input adheres to the input specification provided.

testEvals.input: I threw a boomerang a few years ago. I know live in constant fear.
testEvals.validityText:
The input provided is a joke. It consists of two sentences: "I threw a boomerang a few years ago. I now live in constant fear." The joke plays on the idea that boomerangs return to the thrower, humorously suggesting an exaggerated and ongoing anticipation of its return after many years. This structure fits into the category of a joke. There are no restrictions on the content or length of the joke according to the specification, as humor is subjective. The input is coherent and clearly categorizable as a joke.

OK

testEvals.rule: The output must not include any additional comments, explanations, or justifications for the categorization.

The humor arises from the play on words with "guts," which could literal physical guts (which skeletons lack) and metaphorical courage or bravery. There's no restriction on the length of the joke, and the content fits the type of humor described in the specification. There are no indications of non-compliance with the specified requirements.
